Handler A Figure 3: LinkBioMan Design 
(A) The video handler transcodes the input video stream. (B) The decision framework then ingests the input 
frames and audio buffers, producing results which are saved to (C) the database. (D) The scheduler ensures that 
the results from the decision framework are generated at the user-specified rates and synchronized across the 
framework by controlling the video stream to each of the modules. (E) At run time, users can provide feedback 
on the decision framework output (alert, context and caption) for future module fine-tuning. At system startup, the scheduler dynamically builds the decision framework based on the user-
specified system configuration, assigning separate worker processes to each module. Once 
initialization is complete, the video handler transcodes the input video stream and passes the 
transcoded frames and audio buffers to the scheduler. The scheduler then brokers and 
synchronizes the data streams for the modules, each of which typically processes the data at 
different rates. Any data queries or stores to the database are also handled by the scheduler, which 
acts as the mediator among the decision framework, the database and the individual decision 
framework modules.
The decision framework itself is highly modular and houses the analytical capabilities of the vii system. Individual modules are categorized as either primary or secondary depending on their 
input. The input of primary modules is limited to the source data stream, while secondary modules 
may receive input from the data stream and other modules. This leads to a hierarchical module 
structure where modules further up-stream tend to extract low-level features from the data and 
down-stream modules work to fuse these low-level features in meaningful ways, ultimately 
teasing out higher-level semantic concepts that can be used to alert, provide context to, or describe 
a scene to an operator. The modules, for the most part, rely on pre-trained deep neural network 
models, the details of which are described in Table 2. These modules extract information ranging 
from raw features which are interpretable to a machine (i.e. a vector of floats) to more semantic 
features such as entities (i.e. detected objects or attributes of objects in a frame) that are more 
easily interpreted by human beings. 
In one of the system user interfaces, there is also an option for users to provide feedback on the 
system performance. The feedback is automatically recorded in the system database and can be 
extracted later by developers to fine-tune the models. Table 2: LinkBioMan Modules
The table includes information on the input, output, and general description of each of the modules in the 
LinkBioMan decision framework, which is graphically displayed in Figure 1. The right-most column of the 
table, titled Pre-Trained, indicates if the decision framework module is using a pre-trained model. If the 
decision framework module is not using a pre-trained model, then the model has been either fine-tuned or 
trained from scratch on an external dataset, as noted in the Description column. Module Description Input Output Pre-Trained

confidence scores No Audio Feature Extraction and Audio Entity Classification 4.1
Figure 4 depicts audio processing for Audio Feature Extraction and Audio Entity Classification. 
The incoming audio stream is decoded from the MPEG-4 (MP4) file, converted to mono, down-
sampled to 8 kilohertz (kHZ) (if necessary) and added to a circular buffer. All audio processing 
uses a 1-second analysis window, which is typical for non-speech audio event detection [52]. 
When audio processing is initiated by the Scheduler, the Audio Buffer sends a 1-second audio 
frame to the Audio Feature Extraction module, that converts the acoustic waveform into feature 
vectors.
Two feature sets are calculated from the acoustic waveform: VGGish embeddings and cortical 
features. These two feature sets capture different information from the acoustic waveform, with 
the former engineered using deep learning and the latter designed after the responses from cortical 
neurons in the brain. We incorporate both feature sets as shown in Figure 4. Figure 4: Audio Processing 
(A) Audio is extracted from the input video, pre-processed, and stored in a 1-second circular buffer. (B) Two 
feature sets, VGGish and cortical, are extracted from the audio waveform and sent, along with audio entity 
probabilities, to later stages of processing in the LinkBioMan Decision Framework (Refer to Figure 1). The VGGish embeddings are provided by Google [52], so named because their architecture is 
inspired by comparable features in the visual domain known as VGG. These features are learned x by a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) trained on a large corpus of audio to capture the 
variability present in real-world sound events. The result is a 128-feature vector for 1-second of 
audio. The cortical features are spectro-temporal features based on the receptive fields of cortical 
neurons measured in ferret [60]. These features (described in detail in [54]) are calculated by first 
computing the cochleagram, a time-frequency representation (similar to a spectrogram) that 
incorporates non-linearities present in the mammalian cochlea and auditory periphery. The 
cochleagram is then filtered using a large bank of two-dimensional Gabor filters spanning different 
temporal and spectral modulations. The resulting representation is a 7680-dimensional feature 
vector.
The VGGish embeddings are sent to the Audio Entity Classification module; VGGish features 
were selected in lieu of cortical features after comparison of cross-validation performance. This 
module is composed of a support vector machine (SVM) that outputs the probability that each of 
73 audio entities is
